task_description: Facing the building to your West (approx. 278°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to see the full vertical extent (base to roofline) of the building ahead to estimate height, so I should tilt the camera upward first.
The view is now facing north rather than the target building to the west, so I should rotate left to re-align with the building while keeping the upward pitch to capture its top.
To estimate height I need to see the roofline, so I should tilt up while staying pointed west toward the building.
The heading has reset to north again, so I must rotate left to face west toward the target building while keeping the upward pitch for height estimation.
I need a stable view that includes both the building facade and roofline, so I'll tilt up to capture the top while facing west.
The view is again pointed north instead of at the west-facing target building, so I should rotate left to 270° while keeping pitch up.
To estimate height I need the roof in frame, so I'll look up while staying oriented west toward the building.
I must reorient to the west (270°) where the building is, since the current view is north at an upward pitch.
This is looping without ever giving a usable view of the building; I should move laterally to get a clearer, more complete facade for height estimation.
Now I need to face west toward the target building from this new position to make the height estimate.
With the building presumably in front, I should tilt up to include the roofline and upper floors for a height estimate.
The camera is again facing north; to view the west building while keeping the upward pitch, rotate left to 270°.
Since rotating up keeps resetting the heading, I should instead estimate height from this level view by using visible story count and typical floor heights.
